title: Visualizing the Forest Conversion
text:
### GETTING THE LIBRARIES
1if (!require(pacman))
  install.packages(pacman)


pacman::p_load(tidyverse,
               tidytuesdayR,
               dlookr,
2               formattable)


1

This block is to check if pacman package is installed or not, if it isn’t then the package will be installed.

2

p_load is a function from pacman package to load other packages, if isn’t installed pacman will handle the installation.

title: Visualizing the Forest Conversion
text:
Data-set

# Getting the Data using the tidytuesdayR package 
deforestation_data <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2021, week = 15)

# Getting all the underlying data in the dataset
forest        <- deforestation_data$forest
forest_area   <- deforestation_data$forest_area
brazil_loss   <- deforestation_data$brazil_loss
soyabean_use  <- deforestation_data$soybean_use
vegetable_oil <- deforestation_data$vegetable_oil
deforestation_by_source <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-04-06/deforestation_by_source.csv')

The Global Deforestation data-set were published by Hannah Ritchie and Max Roser (2021) in the Our World in Data journal. This data-set contains comprehensive information on global forest cover, deforestation, and related factors. It includes multiple datas:

forest : Data on net forest conversion and changes in forest cover by country over time.
forest_area : Information on the change in global forest area as a percent of the global forest area.
brazil_loss : Details on the loss of Brazilian forest due to specific causes.
soybean_use : Data on soybean production and use by year and country.
vegetable_oil : Vegetable oil production by crop type and year.


Forest Data

# Get basic information about the dataset
1# The properties of the data
forest |>
2  diagnose() |>
3  formattable()


1

Not displaying the output since it doesn’t have much significance.

2

The diagnose() is used for data profiling, data quality assessment, and diagnostics.

3

The formattable package is used to create formatted tables and data frames for better data visualization. This package is particularly useful for creating visually appealing and informative tables for data analysis and reporting.




The Forest dataset contains information on the change in forest area every 5 years. With 475 observations, the dataset consists of the 4 variables: entity(country), code, year, and the net forest conversion in hectares. The column code has some missing values around 1% and we won’t be using that column anyway since we have entity column.


Forest Area Data

# Get basic information about the dataset
# The properties of the data   
1forest_area |>
  diagnose() |>
  formattable()


1

Not displaying the output since it doesn’t have much significance.




The Forest area dataset looks at the change in global forest area as a percent of global forest area amongst a sample of 7846 observations. The data collected consists of 4 variables: entity, code, year, and percent of global forest area. The column code has some missing values around 13% and we won’t be using that column anyway since we have entity column.


Brazil Loss Data

# Get basic information about the dataset
# The properties of the data
1brazil_loss |>
  diagnose() |>
  formattable()


1

Not displaying the output since it doesn’t have much significance.




The Brazil loss dataset compares loss of Brazilian forest across different types of forest disturbances.13 observations are analyzed amongst 14 variables which include entity, code, year, commercial crops, flooding, natural disturbances, pasture for livestock, logging for lumber, fire loss, mining, infrastructure, roads, tree plantations, and small scale clearing. And we found no missing values in the data after running diagnosis() on top of it.


Soybean Usage Data

# Get basic information about the dataset
# The properties of the data
soyabean_use |>
  diagnose() |>
  formattable()

The data-set called Soybean usage data-set consists of information relating to soybean production and use by year and country. 9897 observations were analyzed across 6 variables: entity, code, year, use for human food (e.g., tempeh, tofu), used for animal food, and processed into vegetable oil/bio-fuel/processed animal feed. The columns animal_feed and processed are having significant missing values.


Vegetable oil Data

# Get basic information about the dataset
# The properties of the data
vegetable_oil |>
  diagnose() |>
  formattable()

In the vegetable oil data-set, 143,832 observations were used to analyze the vegetable oil production by crop type and year. Additionally, the variables consisted of entity, code, year, crop oil and production which contains the production vegetable oil, and oil production in tons. The column production is having significant missing values.


Deforestation by Source

# The properties of the data
1deforestation_by_source |>
  diagnose() |>
  formattable()


1

Not displaying the output since it doesn’t have much significance.




10 observations within the deforestation by source dataset compared different farming entities to forest loss by year. The dataset includes four variables: entity, country, year, and forest loss. The column code has some missing values around 100% and we won’t be using that column anyway since we have entity column.


Why we chose this data-set?
The selection of data-sets for this project is driven by both technical and analytical considerations, particularly related to data visualization. Moreover, deforestation is a serious environmental problem with far-reaching effects. Understanding its trends, drivers, and impacts is critical for informed decision-making and environmental protection. The data-set from Our World in Data provides a reliable data with less junk data and also it contains comprehensive set of variables related to deforestation in this scenario. In the context of data visualization, the technical characteristics of a dataset (cleanliness, structure, consistency) play a key role in creating clear and insightful visualizations.
The data-set is well-structured, making them suitable for editing and visualizing data. It contains various tables like forest, brazil_loss, soybean_use, forest_area, vegetable_oil and deforestation_by_source that allows analysis to target specific aspects of deforestation. These dimensions enable multi-layered analysis and visualization, allowing you to investigate different aspects of a problem. Different variables and data dimensions allow you to create diverse visualizations to consider different aspects of deforestation.
The richness of the data-set provides many opportunities to create effective data visualizations. From time series graphs to choropleth maps to scatter plots, there are many visualization techniques that can effectively convey complex information. In summary, the selection of this data-set is driven by its technical suitability for analysis and its relevance to the critical issue of deforestation.

title: Visualizing the Forest Conversion
text:
Questions
The two questions to be answered are:
Question 1: What does the global forest area look like over past 3 decades, highlighting the trends of forest area conversion?
Question 2: How has the production of Soya bean in Africa changed over time, and how does it impact the afforestation or deforestation rates?

title: Visualizing the Forest Conversion
text:
Analysis plan
So we have come with approaches for both of the questions and are described below.

Approach for question 1
For this plot, we wanted to visualize how the global area under forests has changed over the years. We wanted to represent this data in a graphical manner and show how reducing forest cover over the years could be related to other ecological changes taking place. To visualize the TidyTuesday data-set which was sourced from Our World in Data, we are planning to clean it further to only get certain parts that are required using dplyr. Out of the data involved we will be mostly focusing in the forest data which contains our columns of focus which is net_forest_conversion, year and country. From our initial analysis, we would not need to create any new variable using the data-set.
And coming the actual visualization part the comparison of the plot will be done through years 1990-2015 as we have slightly better recorded data for these years and using this we should be able to show an overview of changes in forest cover over the past years using ggplot. We are planning to create a map plot for the data of forest area and for specific years across the world using the rnaturalearth, ggmap, cowplot and plotly packages. The mapping of data from data-set to the map plot can also be done using geocode() function which we will be exploring as well.


Approach for question 2
For this plot, we want to visualize the trend in the production of soybean over the years in the continent of Africa. To perform this task, we are going to use the TidyTuesday data-set which was sourced from Our World in Data and perform data manipulation to obtain a new column showing the total production of soybean. Out of the data involved we will be mostly focusing in the soyabean_use data and columns present in the table are - human_food ,animal_feed and processed. We will then use ggplot to create a line graph to visualize the rate of change in production. Furthermore, we will compare and correlate the increase or decrease in soybean production with the rates of deforestation and afforestation to determine the general trend in both. This data comparison will be done for the years 1990-2013, as the data-set provides an abundance of useful insights. We also might use other data present in the data-set to get some correlation.






Note:



And since these are the approaches we intend to explore and solve the problem statement which we came up with, bits and pieces of the approach might change.

title: About
text:
This project was developed by The Plotting Pandas for INFO 526 - Data Analysis and Visualization at the University of Arizona, taught by Dr. Greg Chism. The team is comprised of the following team members.

Megan Hokama: Third-year Ph.D. student in Educational Psychology at University of Arizona.
Maria SURESH: First-year graduate student pursuing Data Science at University of Arizona.
Shakir Ahmed: First-year graduate student pursuing Data Science at University of Arizona.
Eshaan Mathakari: First-year graduate student pursuing Data Science at University of Arizona.
Bharath Velamala: First-year graduate student in Data Science at University of Arizona.

title: Project title
text:
Math Expressions
You can write LaTeX math expressions inside a pair of dollar signs, e.g. $\alpha+\beta$ renders \(\alpha + \beta\). You can use the display style with double dollar signs:
$$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$
\[
\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i
\]
Limitations:

The source code of a LaTeX math expression must be in one line, unless it is inside a pair of double dollar signs, in which case the starting $$ must appear in the very beginning of a line, followed immediately by a non-space character, and the ending $$ must be at the end of a line, led by a non-space character;
There should not be spaces after the opening $ or before the closing $.

title: Project title
text:
Feeling adventurous?

You are welcomed to use the default styling of the slides. In fact, that's what I expect majority of you will do. You will differentiate yourself with the content of your presentation.
But some of you might want to play around with slide styling. Some solutions for this can be found at https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs.
